prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not going to my best friends wedding.
So my best friend (lets call her G) has decided to have her wedding, that's awesome and I'm happy she found the one. 

The issue is G never sent out save the dates, meaning last week we got the actual wedding invitations for a wedding that is happening in 1 month.  

It will be at her grandmother's Ranch and it seems like a pretty nice wedding. 

here is where the issue started. 

a few months ago me and 3 friends decided to plan a trip to Australia to backpack/sightsee for 2 weeks, the trip starts 2 days before the wedding so we can't go. G knew about the trip as we invited her but I'm geussing she forgot. 
she is mad at all of us for not just cancelling the trip and being at her wedding. 

all of us are not super rich so this would be a huge loss if we cancelled the trip. (so we are not) 

I also want to add that she invited 50 people, I asked. and only 20 can make it as she gave 1 month notice. 

she is flipping her shit and acting like we should drop everything for her. 

AITA for not just cancelling my 2 week trip to go to her wedding? 
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person who wrote the story is in the wrong for not attending their best friend's wedding. The friend, G, didn't send save-the-dates and only sent invitations a month before the wedding. The author had planned a trip to Australia with friends, which starts two days before the wedding. They couldn't cancel because of the trip and the financial aspect. G is upset and expects them to drop everything.

First, the timeline is an issue. A month's notice for a wedding is short, especially if someone is planning an international trip. Save-the-dates are usually sent out 6-8 months in advance. G didn't do that, so she's partly responsible for the lack of planning. The author informed her about the trip, so she knew. Now, G is upset, but she didn't plan ahead. The author and friends aren't wealthy, so cancelling would mean losing money and missing out on the trip. 

Also, G invited 50 people, but only 20 can attend. That shows maybe others had similar conflicts. The author isn't the only one skipping because of planning. The friends might have other commitments or trips planned. 

The author isn't in the wrong because they communicated their plans upfront, G didn't plan properly, and the trip was financially significant. The anger from G seems misplaced. So, the answer should be B.
